context: a sample note on serous otitis media   (medical transcription sample report)
serous otitis media, better known as middle ear fluid, is the most common condition causing hearing loss in children.

this space can become filled with fluid during colds or upper respiratory infections.

the eustachian tube does not drain well in children.
because children need hearing to learn speech, hearing loss from fluid in the middle ear can result in speech delay.
children begin to speak some words by 18 months.
children with fluid in both ears can show significant delay in their use of language.
when there is a hearing loss, even a mild one, the spoken words of parents and siblings are distorted to the child with fluid in the ears.
most children will have at least one ear infection before the age of four.
usually, the presence of fluid results in a "mild conductive hearing loss."
this could be as much as 30% hearing loss overall.
